de.hu.gralog.graph.alg
Interface Algorithm

All Superinterfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public interface Algorithm
extends java.io.Serializable

This interface has to be implement by all GraLog algorithms. An algorithm in GraLog is basically a JavaBean with an execute-function defined by this interface. Here we give only a short introduction to JavaBeans if you are not familar with JavaBeans please refer to Java Bean Specification.

With the help of JavaBeans algorithms in gralog can be hugely customized which means that they can take arbitrary parameters and provide their own gui-elements for customizing these parameters.

Lets suppose you want to implement an algorithm which takes two parameters:

  • a parameter counter which should be a positive integer
  • a required parameter graph which should be a DirectedGraph whose vertexes extend LabeledGraphVertex and whose edges extend DefaultEdge.

The first thing you have to do is to implement your Algorithm-Class which should look something like this: 

                public class YourAlgorithm implements Algorithm {
 
                        private int counter;
                        private DirectedGraph graph;
 
                        public void setCounter( int counter ) {
                                this.counter = counter;
                        }
 
                        public int getCounter() {
                                return counter;
                        }
 
                        public void setGraph( DirectedGraph graph ) {
                                this.graph = graph;
                        }
 
                        public DirectedGraph getGraph() {
                                return graph;
                        }
 
                        public AlgorithmResult execute() throws InvalidPropertyValuesException, UserException {
                                InvalidPropertyValuesException e = new InvalidPropertyValuesException();
 
                                if ( getGraph() == null )
                                        e.addPropertyError( "graph", InvalidPropertyValuesException.PROPERTY_REQUIRED );
                                if ( getCounter() <= 0 )
                                        e.addPropertyError( "counter", InvalidPropertyValuesException.GREATER_ZERO ); 
                                if ( e.hasErrors() )
                                        throw e;
 
                                // do something and build result
                                return result;
                        }
                }

As you can see each parameter is reflected as a member variable of YourAlgorithm. Furthermore there are two functions for each parameter which are called getter and setter ( the naming convention for these functions comes from the JavaBeans-Specification ). Since there is a getter and a setter for each parameter GraLog knows that YourAlgorithm takes two parameters: counter and graph. Before the user executes YourAlgorithm GraLog allows the user to edit these parameters, so when execute is called you can suppose that all parameters are set according to the users opinion.

As we have said there are restrictions on the parameters. So the first thing you should do is to check for these restrictions in your execute-method. In this case it is checked whether graph is not equal to null and counter is creater than zero and if not an InvalidPropertyValuesException is thrown which gives the user the possibility to alter his input.

The next step is to define a BeanInfo for YourAlgorithm. The easiest way to do this is to define a class YourAlgorithmBeanInfo - the naming convention again comes from JavaBean - in the same package as YourAlgorithm, which should look like this: 

        public class YourAlgorithmBeanInfo extends SimpleBeanInfo {
 
                private static final BeanDescriptor BEAN_DESCRIPTOR = new BeanDescriptor( YourAlgorithm.class );
                private static final PropertyDescriptor[] PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS = new PropertyDescriptor[2];
 
                static {
                        BEAN_DESCRIPTOR.setDisplayName( "A name for YourAlgorithm" );
                        BEAN_DESCRIPTOR.setShortDescription( 
                                        "A description for your algorithm in html." );

                        try {
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[0] = new PropertyDescriptor( "counter", YourAlgorithm.class );
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[0].setShortDescription( "A description for the property counter." );
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[1] = new ChooseGraphPropertyDescriptor( "graph", YourAlgorithm.class, new LabeledDirectedGraphTypeInfo() );
                                PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS[1].setShortDescription( "A description for the property graph." );
                        } catch( IntrospectionException e ) {
                                e.printStackTrace();
                        }

                        public BeanDescriptor getBeanDescriptor() {
                                return BEAN_DESCRIPTOR;
                        }

                        public PropertyDescriptor[] getPropertyDescriptors() {
                                return PROPERTY_DESCRIPTORS;
                        }
        }

YourAlgorithmBeanInfo basically defines a so called BeanDescriptor and an array of PropertyDescriptor one for each parameter. The BeanDescriptor describes properties of the algorithm such as a name and a description in html. Each PropertyDescriptor describes a property of your Algorithm. Currently there are two kinds of PropertyDescriptors in GraLog:

Class Description
PropertyDescriptor This PropertyDescriptors should be used for all basic types like boolean, int, double, String .. . It offers a standard editor for these types.
ChooseGraphPropertyDescriptor This PropertyDescriptor should be used whenever you want the user to choose one of the currently opened graphs in GraLog. It allows to filter those which are of a certain type - in the example of type LabeledDirectedGraph.

The last thing you have to do in your algorithm ( after making your calculations ) is to return an AlgorithmResult. Please refer to the documentation of AlgorithmResult how to do this.

Author:
Sebastian

Method Summary
 AlgorithmResult execute()
          This function is called when all parameters have been set by the user.
 

Method Detail

execute

AlgorithmResult execute()
                        throws InvalidPropertyValuesException,
                               UserException
This function is called when all parameters have been set by the user. It returns an AlgorithmResult which describes the output of your algorithm.

Throws:
InvalidPropertyValuesException - should be thrown if not all parameters where set correctly
UserException - should be thrown if an error occurs during your calculations and you know what went wrong
